Best trails in Grand Canyon National Park

# Best trails in Grand Canyon National Park

DangerStage 2 Fire Restrictions are in effect as of October 31, 2025

·

## 4.6(106,468 reviews)

·

## [United States](https://www.alltrails.com/us "United States")  :   \#12 of 60 [national parks](https://www.alltrails.com/us/national-parks "National Parks")

[All photos](https://www.alltrails.com/parks/us/arizona/grand-canyon-national-park/photos)

Grand Canyon National Park in northwestern Arizona is an iconic destination at the top of many travelers' bucket lists. The highlight of the park, of course, is a gorge carved by the Colorado River. The Grand Canyon is the largest canyon in the United States, measuring up to %{18\_miles} wide, %{277\_miles} long, and %{6000\_feet} deep! The Colorado River has been carving the canyon for more than 5 million years. The process has revealed rock layers that are much older — the youngest rock layer, the Kaibab Formation, is 270 million years old!

Hiking is one of the best ways to experience this amazing geological wonder, and the South Rim of the park offers a trail for everyone. Short, family-friendly hikes offer sweeping vistas of the canyon from viewpoints along the rim. For experienced hikers, there are several trails that descend into the canyon with epic views along the way. No matter which trail you choose, make sure you're prepared before setting out. Take enough food and water, and don't forget sun protection. Go slowly and know your limits. Hikes into the canyon can be especially deceptive — remember to save enough energy for the hike back up to the rim.

In addition to driving, there are [other ways to travel to the South Rim](https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/directions_s_rim.htm). Grand Canyon Airport is about %{7\_miles} from the South Rim, and you can take a flight there from the Las Vegas area and a few nearby cities. [Buses](https://www.nps.gov/grca/getinvolved/cua-list.htm) are also available, including the [shuttle from the nearby town of Tusayan](https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/tusayan-route-purple.htm), which operates from late May through early September. If you're interested in the scenic route, Amtrak offers service to Flagstaff, or you can take the historic [Grand Canyon Railway](https://www.thetrain.com/) from the town of Williams right to the South Rim!

Once you've arrived at the South Rim, there are lots of [ways to get around the park](https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/gettingaround.htm). Guided tours are available by bus, bicycle, or even mule! If you want to explore the park at your own pace, the [free shuttle](https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/shuttle-buses.htm) is your best bet. There are 4 shuttle routes, and 3 of them operate year-round. The Hermits Rest (Red) Route operates from March through November, and the road is closed to private vehicles during that time. You don't need a ticket to ride the shuttle, and they arrive at clearly marked stops every 15 to 30 minutes.

The best time to visit the Grand Canyon is in spring and fall when the weather is mildest. The South Rim of the park is open 24 hours a day, year-round, though it can be quite busy in summer. If you've visited the South Rim before and are looking to shake the crowds, check out some less-traveled hikes on the North Rim!

There is an [entrance fee](https://www.nps.gov/grca/planyourvisit/fees.htm) to visit the park, which you can pay online in advance or in person at various locations in and around the park.

    ### [\#1 \- South Kaibab Trail to Ooh Aah Point](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-ooh-aah-point)



    [4.8(10354)\\
    \\
    ·Moderate\\
    \\
    ·2.0 mi\\
    \\
    ·Est. 1–1.5 hr](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-ooh-aah-point "South Kaibab Trail to Ooh Aah Point") [This "halfway" point to Cedar Ridge is a beautiful hike all in itself. This is the most accessible view of the canyon from the South Kaibab Trailhead and is best for families with young children. If you want to get away from the crowd at the top of the rim, but don't want to go on an all-day hike, this is a good option. Once you reach the end of the trail, you will understand why this lookout is named "Ooh Ahh" after seeing the incredible views.](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-ooh-aah-point "South Kaibab Trail to Ooh Aah Point")

    ### [\#2 \- South Kaibab Trail to Cedar Ridge](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail)



    [4.9(8511)\\
    \\
    ·Hard\\
    \\
    ·3.2 mi\\
    \\
    ·Est. 2–2.5 hr](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail "South Kaibab Trail to Cedar Ridge") [The South Kaibab Trail begins south of Yaki Point on Yaki Point Road. This trail is suitable for a day hike to the mule-hitching post at Cedar Ridge. It offers incredible views for a relatively short hike, but it is steep and lacks water and shade. Seasonal water is available at the trailhead.\\
    \\
    In winter or early spring, the upper portion of the trail can be extremely icy, while summer months may bring thunderstorms. Notably, this is the only trail in Grand Canyon National Park that follows a...](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail "South Kaibab Trail to Cedar Ridge")

    ### [\#3 \- South Kaibab Trail to Skeleton Point](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-skeleton-point)



    [4.9(6408)\\
    \\
    ·Hard\\
    \\
    ·6.1 mi](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-skeleton-point "South Kaibab Trail to Skeleton Point") [This is a must-see viewpoint along the Grand Canyon South Rim and is perfect for a day hike. There are stunning views of the Colorado River from this viewpoint, as well as the beautiful desert canyon landscape. This trail is tough and gradually descends to Skeleton Point. Other incredible 360-degree vistas are located at Ooh Aah Point and Cedar Ridge.\\
    \\
    On the way back, the hike is all uphill so save some energy and snacks! For those who wish to hike further along the South Kaibab Trail, you...](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-skeleton-point "South Kaibab Trail to Skeleton Point")

    ### [\#4 \- 1.5 Mile Resthouse via Bright Angel Trail](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/15-mile-resthouse-via-bright-angel-trail)



    [4.8(8558)\\
    \\
    ·Hard\\
    \\
    ·3.6 mi\\
    \\
    ·Est. 2–2.5 hr](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/15-mile-resthouse-via-bright-angel-trail "1.5 Mile Resthouse via Bright Angel Trail") [This route travels along the Bright Angel Trail and ends at the 1.5 Mile Resthouse. This is one of the shorter routes in the canyon, and one of the most popular ones as well. The trail is challenging, with over 1,000ft of elevation gain along the way, therefore it is important to plan and prepare ahead of time. At some points of the day, the canyon walls provide some shade, however, there are also exposed areas so bring sun protection.](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/15-mile-resthouse-via-bright-angel-trail "1.5 Mile Resthouse via Bright Angel Trail")

    ### [\#5 \- Bright Angel Trail](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/bright-angel-trail--11)



    [4.8(5163)\\
    \\
    ·Hard\\
    \\
    ·16.4 mi](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/bright-angel-trail--11 "Bright Angel Trail") [The Bright Angel Trail is a challenging and adventurous route in the Grand Canyon. The trail begins in Grand Canyon Village on the South Rim, with several rest houses and water along the way. Since the trail is out and back, you can turn around whenever you want. It is not suggested that you do the full route in one day but rather in sections along a multi-day backpacking trip.\\
    \\
    The trail offers iconic views of the canyon and access to the Colorado River for those up to the challenge. If...](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/bright-angel-trail--11 "Bright Angel Trail")

    ### [\#6 \- 3-Mile Resthouse via Bright Angel Trail](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/three-mile-resthouse-via-bright-angel-trail)



    [4.8(4871)\\
    \\
    ·Hard\\
    \\
    ·6.4 mi](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/three-mile-resthouse-via-bright-angel-trail "3-Mile Resthouse via Bright Angel Trail") [3-Mile Resthouse via Bright Angel Trail is one of the most popular trails in the Grand Canyon and is one of several Bright Angel Trail hikes available. The route begins at the Bright Angel Trailhead.\\
    \\
    This route offers gorgeous views, so remember to stop often for photos. The earlier you begin the hike, the fewer crowds. The route ends at the 3-Mile Resthouse, but there are options for shortening and lengthening your journey. \\
    \\
    You may choose to stop at the 1.5 Mile Resthouse or continue on...](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/three-mile-resthouse-via-bright-angel-trail "3-Mile Resthouse via Bright Angel Trail")

    ### [\#7 \- South Kaibab Trail to Phantom Ranch](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-phantom-ranch)



    [4.9(3104)\\
    \\
    ·Hard\\
    \\
    ·14.8 mi](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-phantom-ranch "South Kaibab Trail to Phantom Ranch") [This route features a fantastic descent into the canyon with a difficult ascent back up. The trail is challenging and requires preparation, but it is a must-do multi-day trip in the park. From the trailhead, the path begins with switchbacks known as "the chimney" and descends steeply and narrowly through the canyon. Along the way, there are several stunning vantage points, including Ooh Ahh Point and Cedar Ridge. Wear sturdy footwear because the terrain can be uneven and rocky in some places....](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-phantom-ranch "South Kaibab Trail to Phantom Ranch")

The mostly paved trail is lined with markers that highlight the canyon's geological history, making it an excellent choice for those seeking both scenic beauty and educational opportunities. Mather Point, a popular overlook, provides a breathtaking panorama and is easily accessible from the visitor's center.   \\
    \\
    A particularly scenic section of the trail lies between the Yavapai...](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/grand-canyon-rim-mules-to-mather-point "Rim Trail: Mather Point to Bright Angel Trailhead")

    ### [\#9 \- South Kaibab, Phantom Ranch, and Bright Angel Trail](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-phantom-ranch-and-bright-angel-trail-loop)



    [4.9(5146)\\
    \\
    ·Strenuous\\
    \\
    ·17.3 mi](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-phantom-ranch-and-bright-angel-trail-loop "South Kaibab, Phantom Ranch, and Bright Angel Trail") [This is a combination of two extremely classic routes in the historic Grand Canyon National Park. \\
    \\
    Starting from the South Kaibab Trail, this easy-to-follow trail has awe-inspiring views along the rim and also leads to the Colorado River. There are many series of switchbacks leading up and down the canyon. It's challenging and sometimes steep, however, the adventure and views are worth the effort. \\
    \\
    If completing this trail as a day hike, it is best to start early. If backpacking this route,...](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-phantom-ranch-and-bright-angel-trail-loop "South Kaibab, Phantom Ranch, and Bright Angel Trail")

10. [![Havasupai Gardens Campground via Bright Angel-0](https://www.alltrails.com/api/alltrails/v2/trails/10304374/photos/0?key=3p0t5s6b5g4g0e8k3c1j3w7y5c3m4t8i&size=large)\\
    \\
    ![Havasupai Gardens Campground via Bright Angel-1](https://www.alltrails.com/api/alltrails/v2/trails/10304374/photos/0?key=3p0t5s6b5g4g0e8k3c1j3w7y5c3m4t8i&size=large)\\
    \\
    ![Havasupai Gardens Campground via Bright Angel-2](https://www.alltrails.com/api/alltrails/v2/trails/10304374/photos/0?key=3p0t5s6b5g4g0e8k3c1j3w7y5c3m4t8i&size=large)\\
    \\
    ![Havasupai Gardens Campground via Bright Angel-3](https://www.alltrails.com/api/alltrails/v2/trails/10304374/photos/0?key=3p0t5s6b5g4g0e8k3c1j3w7y5c3m4t8i&size=large)\\
    \\
    ![Havasupai Gardens Campground via Bright Angel-4](https://www.alltrails.com/api/alltrails/v2/trails/10304374/photos/0?key=3p0t5s6b5g4g0e8k3c1j3w7y5c3m4t8i&size=large)](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/havasupai-garden-campground-via-bright-angel-one-way)







    ### [\#10 \- Havasupai Gardens Campground via Bright Angel](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/havasupai-garden-campground-via-bright-angel-one-way)



    [4.9(2330)\\
    \\
    ·Hard\\
    \\
    ·4.7 mi](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/havasupai-garden-campground-via-bright-angel-one-way "Havasupai Gardens Campground via Bright Angel") [The Havasupai Gardens Campground can be reached using this point-to-point route which can also be incorporated into a multi-day camping trip. The trail is very well-maintained, clear to follow, and offers stunning canyon views at every turn. Before the 1.5-mile house and on weekends, the trail may be congested. Bring appropriate sun protection, as the trail is primarily exposed to the sun. On the way to the campground, there are restrooms with drinking water available for a portion of the year.](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/havasupai-garden-campground-via-bright-angel-one-way "Havasupai Gardens Campground via Bright Angel")

## Trail reviews for Grand Canyon National Park

139,276 trailgoersBusiest in October

[Gina Difino](https://www.alltrails.com/members/gina-difino)

Dec 16, 2025·Hiking

Easy to parkBathrooms availableGreat conditionsGreat views

What can one say about a iconic hike into the **grand canyon**. Bring lots of water. Give yourself lots of time to ascend. But the payoff is stunning!

Parking:Entry fee, Free, Medium lot

[South Kaibab Trail to Skeleton Point](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-skeleton-point)

[Samuel Smith](https://www.alltrails.com/members/samuel-smith-63)

Beautiful **Grand Canyon** along the rim. Obviously crowded

[Grand Canyon Greenway to Rim Trail](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/grand-canyon-greenway-to-rim-trail)

[Acacia Coates](https://www.alltrails.com/members/acacia-coates)

Nov 27, 2025·Hiking

Easy to parkNot crowdedBathrooms availableDog-friendlyGreat conditionsGreat views

We saw a whole herd of elk on the trail! The views of the **grand canyon** were spectacular. This is a great hike for beginners looking for a walk in nature with beautiful views.

Difficulty:Easy

![Photo 1 of 5](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/location-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)

![Photo 2 of 5](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/location-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)

![Photo 3 of 5](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/location-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)

![Photo 4 of 5](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/location-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)

![Photo 5 of 5](https://www.alltrails.com/mugen/image/location-app-router?url=https%3A%2F%2Fimages.alltrails.com%&w=256&q=75)

[Shoshone Point](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/shoshone-point-trail)

[Timothy D](https://www.alltrails.com/members/timothy-duong-7)

Nov 25, 2025·Hiking

I went all the way down to the Colorado River and Phantom Ranch which adds several miles and around 1500 ft of elevation gain compared to what AllTrails says. Do not attempt a Rim to River to Rim in one day unless you've already completed a 20 mile hike with around 5000 ft of elevation gain before. This will be even harder than that because most of the uphill is towards the end when you are most tired unlike most hikes where the uphill is at the beginning. The best way to do this is to take South Kaibab down and Bright Angel up as South Kaibab has better views of the canyon and Bright Angel has more water refill options (though don't count on them to be running all the time). If you are staying in the **Grand Canyon** Village, take the Hiker's Express shuttle to the South Kaibab trailhead. The weather at the end November was around 25-30 °F at the top in the morning but it quickly warms up once you pass Ooh Aah Point. You'll be quite warm to begin with since the bus is heated, but you should still bring warm layers in case you don't finish before sunset. There was no snow or ice at any point, but some parts were muddy. Since the River Trail and Silver Bridge are closed for construction after checking out the river and Phantom Ranch you need to go back up South Kaibab until you reach the junction for the Tonto trail, where you go west a few miles until you reach Bright Angel at Havasupai Gardens. The water was running at Havasupai Gardens according to the sign, but not at the two resthouses on Bright Angel. At this time of year the temperature never got too hot (the thermometer at Havasupai Gardens read 54 °F at 4 p.m.) so I carried all the water I needed and only ended up drinking around 2 L. It started to get quite cold near the end but since that part is uphill I was warm enough with 2 layers. Overall, this was a stunning hike and I hope to be back for a Rim to Rim once everything is restored.

Conditions:Muddy

[South Kaibab Trail, Tonto Trail, and Bright Angel Trail](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-tonto-and-bright-angel-trail)

Parks

## Frequently asked questions

### Where is the best place to hike in Grand Canyon National Park?

According to users from AllTrails.com, the best place to hike in Grand Canyon National Park is [South Kaibab Trail to Ooh Aah Point](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-trail-to-ooh-aah-point), which has a 4.8 star rating from 10,354 reviews.This trail is 2.0 mi long with an elevation gain of 666 ft.

### What is the longest trail in Grand Canyon National Park?

According to AllTrails.com, the longest trail in Grand Canyon National Park is [Tuckup Trail](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/tuckup-trail--3).This trail is estimated to be 70.2 mi long.

### How many trails are in Grand Canyon National Park?

There are 137 trails in Grand Canyon National Park.These trails have an average 4.6-star ratingfrom NaN AllTrails community reviews.

### Which trail has the most elevation gain in Grand Canyon National Park?

[Rim-to-Rim-to-Rim: South Kaibab, North Kaibab, Bright Angel \[CLOSED\]](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/south-kaibab-to-north-kaibab-to-bright-angel-trail) has the most elevation gain with 11,443 ft of total ascent.The park's runner-up is [Clear Creek Trail via South Kaibab Trail \[CLOSED\]](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/clear-creek-trail--2), which has 8,585 ft of elevation gain.

### Are there camping trails available in Grand Canyon National Park?

According to AllTrails.com, there are 75 camping trails in Grand Canyon National Park and the most popular is [Bright Angel Trail](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/bright-angel-trail--11) with an average 4.8 star rating from 5,163 community reviews.

### Are there running trails available in Grand Canyon National Park?

According to AllTrails.com, there are 18 running trails in Grand Canyon National Park and the most popular is [Shoshone Point](https://www.alltrails.com/trail/us/arizona/shoshone-point-trail) with an average 4.8 star rating from 2,785 community reviews.
